ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You cover a lot of different aspects of national security law, from covert actions to torture to FISA searches.

This course is a great introductory course to the ins and outs of national security law and law in general, with the right balance of international affairs and policy, and law (studying cases and how they set precedent for the present).
I developed a strong foundation in domestic national security law. I learned to apply legal frameworks and stitch in case law into my legal arguments.
Understanding legal aspects on the national security issues

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lots of writing (I'll let you decide whether this is a strength or weakness), kind of a "throw 'em in the deep end" kind of class (also up to you whether that's good or bad)

Strengths: Professor Rangappa was such a great professor; she's so knowledgeable about the subject and so willing to help when students have questions about cases and how law works in general. The separation of cases by different topics is so helpful as well.
Strengths Asha is really engaging. The text can be dry, but shes lively and knowledgeable. Weakness more application. A simulation would be very cool in this class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have any interest in law, policy, or national security, definitely take this course! It's very approachable, and provides a great platform into thinking about topics through legal frameworks.
Absolutely would recommend. Its fundamental to understanding national security and touches on crucial philosophical questions about right of the individual vs protection of the state.

Yes. You will gain build legal analysis on the political issues, which are often missed in the political science classes. Also, it will be a great bridge to your academic endeavors if you are interested in applying a law school.
